Problem:
Consider the complex function \( f(z) = e^{i\omega t}z \), utilized in the context of a linear transformation in the complex plane over time \( t \), where \( \omega \) is a real number representing angular frequency. The evolution of a complex function \( g(z) = az + b \) follows, where \( a \) and \( b \) are complex constants.

If \( f(z) \) is applied to a complex number \( z_0 \) at \( t = 0 \), and then \( g(z) \) is applied without further modification at \( t = T \), is the result the same as directly applying \( g(z) \) at \( t = T \) to \( z_0 \)?
Explanation: The initial application of \( f(z) \) modifies \( z_0 \) through a rotation by \( e^{i\omega T} \), which fundamentally changes the input for \( g(z) \). The latter transformation is then applied to a different starting value, producing a distinct result due to the sequence of transformations.
